lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can recognize and correctly use a or an before singular nouns (e.g., a train, an apple).
supportStrategies: (Grammar) Write “a train / an apple.” Circle first letter. Explain a/an rule.
stretchStrategies: Play a/an swap game. Write nouns on paper strips (e.g. apple, train). Students pick one, walk around asking, “Is it a/an ___?” When correct, they swap strips and continue.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can recognise and identify the initial sounds (c, t, p, a).
supportStrategies: (Phonics) Say /c/, /t/, /a/, /p/. Students repeat, then match to a word in SB.
stretchStrategies: Play a/an swap game. Write nouns on paper strips (e.g. apple, train). Students pick one, walk around asking, “Is it a/an ___?” When correct, they swap strips and continue.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can complete short sentence frames (e.g., It’s a ____.) using the correct article (a or an) and target nouns.
supportStrategies: (Writing) Show board frame: “It’s ___ ___.” Students complete with a/an + toy.
stretchStrategies: Play a/an swap game. Write nouns on paper strips (e.g. apple, train). Students pick one, walk around asking, “Is it a/an ___?” When correct, they swap strips and continue.

items: VYL: colours do not map onto one another (blue/green = blue)

In Vietnamese, final consonants are 'held in' – you don't actually hear them released. But in English, the final consonant of cat, top, rock, and so on are released with a puff of air. Make sure you are aware of this difference.
Do not exist in standard Vietnamese, written or spoken. The hardest part for YLs is learning to pronounce them naturally: there's a dog rather than there is a dog.
